title: Does home-court advantage make a difference?
text:
Home-court advantage in college basketball is real, but maybe not as powerful as it once was. Historically, teams will play better on their own court. Since they aren’t dealing with unfamiliar surroundings, unsupportive crowds, and travel fatigue, it is an advantage. But in today’s game, where each player becomes better than the last-the question arises: is home-court advantage still as impactful across conferences as it used to be?
To find out-let’s take a look at conference winning percentages and how they are affected by home and away games.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(dplyr)
library(ggalt)
library(ggtext)
library(ggrepel)
library(gt)
library(wehoop)

basketball <- read_csv("~/R Projects/SPMC Homework/BasketballStats.csv")

percentage <- basketball |>
  filter(is.na(Conference) == FALSE) |> 
  group_by(Conference) |> 
  summarize(
    total_games = sum(OverallGames),
    total_wins = sum(OverallWins),
    total_conf_wins = sum(ConferenceWin),
    total_conf_losses = sum(ConferenceLoss),
    total_conf_home_wins = sum(HomeWin),
    total_conf_home_losses = sum(HomeLoss),
    total_conf_away_losses = sum(AwayLoss),
    total_conf_away_wins = sum(AwayWin)
  ) |> 
  mutate(
    conference_winning_pct = total_wins / total_games,
    conference_home_winning_pct = total_conf_wins / (total_conf_home_wins + total_conf_home_losses),
    conference_away_winning_pct = total_conf_wins / (total_conf_away_wins + total_conf_away_losses)
  )

big10 <- percentage |> 
  filter(
    Conference == "Big Ten"
  )

big12 <- percentage |> 
  filter(
    Conference == "Big 12"
  )

MW <- percentage |> 
  filter(
    Conference == "Mountain West"
  )

SEC <- percentage |> 
  filter(
    Conference == "SEC"
  )

MAC <- percentage |> 
  filter(
    Conference == "MAC"
  )

patriot <- percentage |> 
  filter(
    Conference == "Patriot"
  )

ivy <- percentage |> 
  filter(
    Conference == "Ivy League"
  )

bigten <- percentage |>
  filter(
    Conference == "Big Ten"
  )

stat <- percentage |> 
  select(Conference, conference_home_winning_pct, conference_away_winning_pct) |>
  pivot_longer(
    cols = -Conference, 
    names_to = "Type",
    values_to = "Percentage"
  )

ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=stat, aes(x=reorder(Conference, Percentage), weight=Percentage, fill=Type)) +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
  x="Conferences",
  y="Conference Home and Away Win Percentages",
  title="There's no place like home-until teams win while away.",              
  subtitle="Conferences post higher winning percentages in conference away games, challenging home-court advantage.", 
    caption="Source: NCAA | By Madalyn Fox"
  ) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("conference_away_winning_pct" = "red",
                               "conference_home_winning_pct" = "darkgrey"),
                    labels = c("conference_away_winning_pct" = "Away",
                               "conference_home_winning_pct" = "Home")
  ) +
  guides(fill = guide_legend(title = "Conference Winning Percentages")) +
  theme_minimal() + 
   theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 15, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    )









Some conferences, and teams, consistently have a higher away winning percentages when playing teams in their own conference.
What do the numbers look like?


Code
chart4 <- percentage |>
  select(Conference, conference_winning_pct, conference_away_winning_pct, conference_home_winning_pct)

chart4 |> gt() |>
  cols_label(
    conference_winning_pct = "Conference Winning Percentage",
    conference_home_winning_pct = "Home Winning Percentage",
    conference_away_winning_pct = "Away Winning Percentage"
  ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "The Big Ten Dominates the Road",
    subtitle = "The Big Ten is among the best of the conferences when playing away games" 
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
   ) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("By: Madalyn Fox  |  Source: Sports Reference")
  ) |> 
  tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=12)
     )
  ) |>
  opt_row_striping() |> 
  opt_table_lines("none") |>
    fmt_percent(
    columns = c(conference_winning_pct, conference_away_winning_pct, conference_home_winning_pct),
    decimals = 1
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "red"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Conference == "Big Ten")
  )

The Big Ten is more than 5% higher than the ACC when playing on the road, which is a notable margin. Yet, the Big Ten ranks more towards the middle when it comes to home winning percentages. This could suggest that Big Ten teams are still solid at home, their away records set them apart.
How does the Big Ten rank overall?


Code
ggplot() +
  geom_point(
    data=percentage,
    aes(x=total_conf_away_wins, y=total_conf_home_wins, size=total_wins), 
    color ="darkgrey",
    alpha = .3) +
  scale_size(range = c(1,10), name="Total Wins") +
  geom_text_repel(
    data=percentage,
    aes(x=total_conf_away_wins, y=total_conf_home_wins, label=Conference) 
   ) +
  geom_point(
    data=big10,
    aes(x=total_conf_away_wins, y=total_conf_home_wins, size=total_wins), 
    color ="red",
    alpha = .3) +
  labs(
    x= "Total Conference Home Wins",
    y= "Total Conference Away Wins",
    title =  "The Big Ten has more wins on both courts",
    subtitle="The Big Ten Conference, has more away and home wins than other conferences.",
    caption= "Source: Sports Reference | By Madalyn Fox"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
   theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    )









As one of the largest conferences in the country, the Big Ten unsurprisingly ranks toward the top in total wins, both at home and on the road. The ACC, which has the same number of teams, isn’t far behind in overall success but struggles more on the road. How do individual teams in the Big Ten do on the road?


Code
scoringmargin <- read_csv("~/R Projects/SPMC Homework/Teampointmargins.csv")

big10conference <- scoringmargin |>
  filter(Conference == "Big Ten")

ggplot()+
  geom_dumbbell(
    data=big10conference,
    aes(y=reorder(Team,Home), x= Home, xend=Away),
    size = 2.5,
    colour = "grey",
    colour_x = "green",
    colour_xend = "red") +
  labs(
    y= "Big Ten Teams",
    x= "Average Point Margins",
    title="The Big Ten thrives at home", 
    subtitle = "If <span style = 'color:green;'>green</span> is far on the right, they play better at home. If <span style = 'color:red;'>red</span> is on the right, they play better away.",
    caption = "Source: NCAA | By: Madalyn Fox"
  ) + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 12, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_textbox_simple(size = 6.7) 
  )









Every team has better point margins while playing at home, but the extent of the home-court advantage can vary. Some teams maintain competitive point margins away from home, while other teams just struggle significantly when playing on the road.
In the end, home-court advantage may still matter, but it’s clear that in today’s college basketball landscape, the best teams will find ways to win—regardless of the court they’re playing on.

title: Who will win the next major tournament?
text:
With Rory McIlroy finally completing the Grand Slam, one question remains. Who will win the next major tournament? The PGA Championship is scheduled for May 15-18, 2025, and there is plenty of time to place bets. Statistically, the favorites are Rory McIlroy, Scottie Scheffler, Bryson DeChambeau, and defending champion Xander Schauffele - just to name a few. Some other big names include Justin Thomas fresh off his win at the RBC Heritage tournament and the United States Ryder Cup Team Captain Keegan Bradley. Jordan Spieth is also on the radar with the PGA Championship being the last to complete his Grand Slam.
When it comes to majors, it can be the short game that separates the champions from the cut line. Putting - one of the most mentally demanding parts of the game- could make or break a round.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(dplyr)
library(ggrepel)
library(ggbump)
library(gt)
library(wehoop)

putting <- read_csv("~/R Projects/SPMC Homework/PGA Data/putting average.csv")

driving <- read_csv("~/R Projects/SPMC Homework/PGA Data/pga total driving.csv") 

birdieorbetter <- read_csv("~/R Projects/SPMC Homework/PGA Data/birdie or better percentage.csv")

scoringaverage <- read_csv("~/R Projects/SPMC Homework/PGA Data/scoring average.csv")

cuts <- read_csv("~/R Projects/SPMC Homework/PGA Data/consecutive cuts.csv")

strokesgained <- read_csv("~/R Projects/SPMC Homework/PGA Data/strokes gained.csv")

rankings <- read_csv("~/R Projects/SPMC Homework/PGA Data/world and driving rank.csv")

puttingnew <- putting |>
  select(-...6, -...7, -...8)

drivingnew <- driving |>
  select(-MOVEMENT, -PLAYER_ID)

birdieorbetternew <- birdieorbetter |>
  select(-RANK, -MOVEMENT, -PLAYER_ID) |>
  rename(BIRDIEPERCENT = `%`)

cutsnew <- cuts |>
  select(-RANK, -MOVEMENT, -PLAYER_ID) |>
  rename(CUTS = TOTAL)

scoringaveragenew <- scoringaverage |>
  select(-RANK, -MOVEMENT, -PLAYER_ID) |>
  rename(SCORINGAVG = AVG)

strokesgainednew <- strokesgained |>
  select(-RANK, -MOVEMENT, -PLAYER_ID) |>
  rename(SGAVG = AVG)

rankingsnew <- rankings |>
  select(-`...3`, -`...4`)

newstats <- puttingnew |>
  inner_join(drivingnew, by = "PLAYER") |>
  inner_join(cutsnew, by = "PLAYER") |>
  inner_join(scoringaveragenew, by = "PLAYER") |>
  inner_join(birdieorbetternew, by = "PLAYER")

bestplayers <- newstats |>
  filter(
    PLAYER == "Rory McIlroy" |
    PLAYER == "Justin Thomas" |
    PLAYER == "Justin Rose" |
    PLAYER == "Scottie Scheffler" |
    PLAYER == "Ludvig √Öberg" |
    PLAYER == "Harry Hall" |
    PLAYER == "Cam Davis" |
    PLAYER == "Sepp Straka" |
    PLAYER == "Colin Morikawa" |
    PLAYER == "Xander Schauffele" |
    PLAYER == "Sungjae Im" |
    PLAYER == "Russell Henley" |
    PLAYER == "Jordan Spieth"
  )

SS <- bestplayers |>
  filter(
    PLAYER == "Scottie Scheffler"
)

RM <- bestplayers |>
  filter(
    PLAYER == "Rory McIlroy"
  )
SEPP <- bestplayers |>
  filter(
    PLAYER == "Sepp Straka"
  )

Scottie <- rankingsnew |>
  filter(
    PLAYER == "Scottie Scheffler"
  )

Rory <- rankingsnew |>
  filter(
    PLAYER == "Rory McIlroy"
  )

strokesgainedplayers <- strokesgainednew |>
    filter(
    PLAYER == "Rory McIlroy" |
    PLAYER == "Justin Thomas" |
    PLAYER == "Justin Rose" |
    PLAYER == "Scottie Scheffler" |
    PLAYER == "Ludvig √Öberg" |
    PLAYER == "Harry Hall" |
    PLAYER == "Cam Davis" |
    PLAYER == "Sepp Straka" |
    PLAYER == "Colin Morikawa" |
    PLAYER == "Xander Schauffele" |
    PLAYER == "Sungjae Im" |
    PLAYER == "Russell Henley" |
    PLAYER == "Min Woo Lee" |
    PLAYER == "Keegan Bradley" |
    PLAYER == "Jordan Spieth"
  )
  

SS <- strokesgainedplayers |>
  filter(
    PLAYER == "Scottie Scheffler"
  )


RM <- strokesgainedplayers |>
  filter(
    PLAYER == "Rory McIlroy"
  )

tableplayers <- bestplayers |>
  select(-`GIR PUTTS`, -`GREENS HIT`, -`BIRDIE CONVERSION`, -RANK, -TOTAL, -`DISTANCE RANK`, -`ACCURACY RANK`, -`TOTAL STROKES`, -`TOTAL ADJUSTMENT`, -`TOTAL ROUNDS`, -BIRDIEPERCENT, -`TOTAL BIRDIES`, -`TOTAL HOLES`, -`GIR RANK`, -CUTS)

tableplayers |>
  gt() |>
  cols_label(
    SCORINGAVG = "Scoring Average",
    AVG = "Putting Average"
  ) |> 
  tab_header(
    title = "The worst putters still have a chance to win",
    subtitle = "Players with higher putting averages still post some of the best overall scores"
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(

    locations = cells_title("subtitle")) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Madalyn Fox  |  **Source:** PGA")) |>
  tab_style(
    locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
    style = list(
      cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
      cell_text(weight = "bold", size = 12)
    )
    ) |>
  opt_row_striping() |>
  opt_table_lines("none") |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "lightblue"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
    ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = PLAYER == "Scottie Scheffler")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "lightgreen"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
    ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = PLAYER == "Rory McIlroy")

It’s no surprise that the lowest overall scoring averages include the top two players in the world. But while Scottie Scheffler continues to dominate leaderboards, he ranks among the worst in putting averages. On the other hand, Justin Thomas—who has one of the best putting averages on tour. He brings proven success at this very tournament, having won the PGA Championship in both 2017 and 2022. Still, putting is only one piece of the puzzle. On a course like Valhalla, where length and precision are rewarded, performance off the tee can be just as critical. Driving distance and accuracy often set the tone for scoring opportunities—and mistakes.


Code
topplayers <- rankingsnew |>
  filter(
    PLAYER == "Scottie Scheffler" |
    PLAYER == "Sepp Straka" |
    PLAYER == "Rory McIlroy" |
    PLAYER == "Justin Thomas" |
    PLAYER == "Russell Henley" |
    PLAYER == "Jordan Spieth" |
    PLAYER == "Keegan Bradley" |
    PLAYER == "Ludvig √Öberg"
  )

ggplot() +
  geom_point(data=rankingsnew, aes(x=`ACCURACY RANK`, y=`DISTANCE RANK`, size=`PGA RANKING`),
    alpha = .1) +
  scale_size(range = c(10, 1), name="PGA Ranking") +
geom_point(
  data=Scottie, 
  aes(x=`ACCURACY RANK`, y=`DISTANCE RANK`, size=`PGA RANKING`), color="lightblue") +
  geom_point(
    data=Rory, 
    aes(x=`ACCURACY RANK`, y=`DISTANCE RANK`, size=`PGA RANKING`), color="lightgreen") +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 75.0) +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 75.0) +
  geom_text_repel(
    data=topplayers,
    aes(x=`ACCURACY RANK`, y=`DISTANCE RANK`, label=PLAYER)) + 
  geom_text(aes(x=30, y=20, label="Good Rankings"), color="blue") +
  geom_text(aes(x=120, y=150, label="Bad Rankings"), color="blue") +
  labs(
    x="Accuracy Ranking", 
    y="Distance Ranking", 
    title="Power and precision aren't everything", 
    subtitle="Top performers rank outside the best driving distance and accuracy zones.", 
    caption="Source: PGA | By Madalyn Fox"
    ) + 
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size =15, face = "bold"),
     axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=9), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









The lower the better, and in this case, Jordan Spieth and Keegan Bradley outrank some of the world’s top players. Both are excelling in driving distance and accuracy—two key factors at a course like Valhalla. Spieth has quietly put together one of his most consistent seasons off the tee, while Bradley’s precision continues to keep him in contention, especially on tight setups.
Looking at overall strokes gained—a statistic that combines performances from driving, approach shots, short game, and putting—some players are consistently at the top. It is a reliable way to measure which players are truly playing the most well-rounded golf heading into the next major.


Code
ggplot() + geom_bar(data=strokesgainedplayers, aes(x=reorder(PLAYER,SGAVG), weight=SGAVG)) +
geom_bar(data=SS, aes(x=reorder(PLAYER,SGAVG), weight=SGAVG), fill="lightblue") +
  geom_bar(data=RM, aes(x=reorder(PLAYER,SGAVG), weight=SGAVG), fill="lightgreen") +
  coord_flip() + 
  labs(
    x="", 
    y="Average Stokes Gained", 
    title="Built to win, at least on paper", 
    subtitle="Strokes gained trends highlight the top two players to win the next major.", 
    caption="Source: PGA | By Madalyn Fox"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









While this analysis excludes LIV players due to the unavailability of data, the numbers are still strong predictors of who’s trending upward heading into the PGA Championship. By strokes gained in key areas, Scottie Scheffler, Keegan Bradley, and Justin Thomas are all top competitors. Rory McIlroy also has a strong chance but since he won the first major of the year it is unlikely he will win another. Each is well-suited to handle major championship pressure—and has a real chance to lift the Wanamaker Trophy.
